newsitem.title: USA: Edgy session seen ahead for U.S. equities.
newsitem.headline: Edgy session seen ahead for U.S. equities.

text.p: The sharp, late tumble in U.S. financial markets on Wednesday is likely to leave nerves raw at Wall Street's Thursday open.

Analysts said investors could take some comfort from the market's ability to bounce off its lows in the last minutes of trading, a recovery that saw the Dow recoup about a quarter of the more than 120 points it shed during the most intense phase of the sell-off.
The Dow industrials closed at 6746.90, down 86.58 points and the Nasdaq Composite slid 25.31 points to 1348.44.
The mild upswing could lend support to a suddenly jittery market in the opening moments, said analysts.
"I would look for something more stable tomorrow, maybe a bounce back in the morning," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany.
Johnson added, however, that there seemed to be an "edginess" in the market, a mood that given an earnings disappointment or other bad news "could turn an edgy market into a decline."
Analysts were quick to note that stocks, large caps in particular, were due for some form of pullback after enjoying a furious, liquidity-driven January rally.
"Fund inflows are going to be lighter now and it looks like we're going to have a rougher time making money in this market," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
"There's nothing wrong with profit-taking and a lot of these stocks were due for some corrective activity," he added.
Among the stocks hit hardest during Wednesday's late selling were the same top-tier technology names that led the market higher in January.

Intel Corp closed at 157-1/4, down 7-1/2, after dipping as low as 155. Microsoft Corp finished at 98-3/8, down 4-3/4 after a wild day that saw it hit an all-time high 103-1/2 and touch as low as 96-7/8.
Buyers have quickly emerged after every dip in the most recent leg of the bull market, but some analysts said cash could be at least a session slower to re-enter this time around.
"Investors could be on hold for Friday's jobs data," said Guy Truicko, portfolio manager at Unity Management. "People will want to see the employment number before the market renews its uptrend."
